body.div1:
Honorable Assistant Secretary of State Washington, D.C.
Sir: I have the honor to inform the Department of any return May 12th to Basoko from the Lomami River. The following is a brief as count of the manner in which the Arab Slave dealers have been driven from this section of the Kongo Free State.
Upon my arrival at Basoko March2nd Commandant Chaltin informed me he had recieved orders from Inspector of the State, M. Five in the Sankuru River to proceed to Bena- Kamba, in the Lomami River and commence asperations
<pb facs="20170614_144014"
against the Arabs who were supposed to be at that place in large numbers, and if suc- cessful to proceed to Tchari 60 miles farther south occu- py that place, and these re- turn to Bena Kamba, and proceed to Riba-Riba. Nothing was said in This Communication which could be combined into an order to arrack any Arab pasts situated between Isanghi and Kibonge Com- mandant Chatlin invited me to accompany kim, as his guest, but I preferred first to see Stanley Falls under Arab rule, as I had an idea they would revolt in a few months.
I accepted the invitation to come on a Steamer leaving a few weeks after his departure. He left Basoko for Bena- Komba March 7th on board the Steamer "Ville d'anvers" with 200
<pb facs="20170614_144024"
200 Joediers + 2 Krupp 7.5 omm Canon.
The Steamer "Ville de Buxelles" was sent to Equator Station, 500 miles down river to being re-enforcements. I left for Stanley Falls march 4th and remained until March 17th when M.Jobback, The President, Kindly sent me to Basako in the pleau- "launch" A.I.A. in order to cash the "Bruxelles" on her return"
During my stay at the Falls I could see there was a strong feeling amongst the Arabs against the State, and that it only re- quired a very small thing to begin the war against the Govern- ment.
The Vali (or Governor) at the Falls Commonly known as Rachid, but whose real name is Rachid, but whose real name is Rachid. Ben. said Ben. Jama. Marajebe which means, Rachid, (Ben) son of said, (Ben) son of Jama Marajebe) and a nephew of Tippoo Tip was and a nephew of Tippo Tip was exceedingly discourtious to me
when
<pb facs="20170614_144031"
when he learned I intended going to the Lomani.
The position he held was a most expeditionary one; he was, by de- partment of the Governor of the Kongo Free State, by order of the auchoutioud in Brussels, Vali of Stanley Falls, and received by salary of six thousand Francs per anew ($1158.00); he was always furnished with the uniform of a Caplaui Commandant.
The reasons given for placing at the head of government at sanchan important points a man with so notorious a reputation, were, that he would be able to control all the arabs of this region and so prevent any concentrated attack against the State posts. As future events have proved the State were entirely wrong in their estimate of the Arab strength.
The State had a Resident here, M. Tobback, who conducted all
the
<pb facs="20170614_144039"
the affairs of Government and was Commandant of the Past containing 150 soldiers, situated on the right bank of the Kongo. (see map marked Exhibit "B").
Suppose the population at Stanley Falls might be put down at 5000, but it was the greatest Ivory market in Central Africa. While I was there the Agent of the Belgian Factory, purchased in 5 days four (4) tons, worth in Europe 25,000 Francs (or $4833.00). per ton J to say nothing of rubber. We sent down to Stanley Pool aboard the s.s. Archduchess Thiphanie". 18 tons Ivory and 29 tons rubber all the result of four months work.
Upon arrival at Basoko Sfound the "Brussels" not yet arrived, + was compelled to wait until the 25th when the cause in. On board were 150 soldiers and one Lieutenant and a Sergeant; Immediately the Carpentars were set to work and a thing farricade placed entirely aroused her, and on the 27th.
All
<pb facs="20170614_144048"
All being completed we left for Bena Kauba, having on board Leuit de Bock, Sergeant Lamers +myself. 150 soldiers, armed with Albini Rifers, 45,370 cartridges provisions for the officers and 10 tons of rice for the men...
Noching of note occurred, while as- cending the river until March 31st when the decapitated body of a woman was passed, floating down streams. No cause for this apparent murder could be found until that evening the steamer stopped at a large village which was in feawers. Two detach- ments of soldiers were immediately made ready to go ashore, as an Arab raid had evidently been made.
M. de roacks Joak one and I the other reach went to an end of the town and as my men started into the bush they received three shots from the dark- ness of the forest; we charged the pre- firing three valleys white on the rest but could see nothing as might had
fallen.
<pb facs="20170614_144056"
fallen, so returned to the steamer. On the way back found eight bodies of women and children, all headless and some with their legs and arms gone. Mr. de Bock found in the Banana plantation two children and an old woman, who, after some hours, were persuaded to let us what had occurred.
It seems the village had been attacked by a party of Arab slave hunters about 3 o'clock that afternoon. They had captured over a hundred of the in habi- tants, and were engaged in des- troying the Joen when the steamer came in sight. They retreated im mediately, and the shots I received were probably fired by the rear guard.
The next morning we followed their rail some 3 or 4 miles back found the bodies of 20 persons men, women + children, who were too young, old or inform to march rapidly, so
had
<pb facs="20170614_144103"
had been murdered in order to allow the caraven to retreat as fast as possible.
As we had orders to proceed with all despatch and join Com- mandant Chaltin at Bena. Kamba M. de Bocko did not consider him- self justified in pursuing farther the enemy.
Such seems as this village pre- sented were afterwards of not unfre- quent occurence.
April 10th another body was passed, but no xause for teach could be discovered.
The Steamer arrived at Bema- Kamba the next day, and instead of finding a great number of Arabs, who were supposed to be fortfied here, nothing was to be seen but the ruins of the Past established by the State some years ago. This place was occupied lasy years ago. This place was occupied last year as the Headquarters of the Company known as the "Kalanga Lyndicate, of which
Mr
<pb facs="20170614_144110"
Mr. Hodistin was the chief, and was destroyed by the Arabs at the same time they murdered him and his Expedition while on the way to Riba-Riba.
Here we found letters directing the steamers to come to Lhome, 20 miles farther up. We left immediately and after a day and a half arrived the S.S. Villa d'anvers" was here, + the Captain gave us Commandant Chaltins orders to march without delay to Tchain + join him.
We left the next morning, + that afternoon encountered the Commandant returning. He had been most-success- ful defeating the Arabs m an open fight, and completely destroying the town of Jchari, which consisted of 1200 houses and 15000 people two days later both steamers after for Bena Kamba, where the Expedition was to be re-organized for its March to Riba-Riba, through a section of country said to be defeuded
by
<pb facs="20170614_144123"
by a coting body of arabs.
Small pay had appeared amongst the soldiers and porters one white officer, Mr. Coppee also had it. The Surgeon Dr. Dupont had a bad case of dysentery, so, as the "Villa d' Anvers" was leaving for Basko in a few days it was decided to send these two offices back.
March 21st we left Bena Kamba for Riba-Riba-505 strong district whe'd formed into columns as follows Cost. Vanguard Lequeant Nachan 66,soldiers Cannon. M. Mohen. 6. -44 Carriers for Canon- Commandant Chaltin 14" Co. "B" Caprain Marek. 75" Luggage Provisions Lentove So Carriers for Luggage etc. Co. "C"- Lieutenant De Bock. 90" Co. "II"- Rear Geard, Leutenat James. 31." Total Soldiers= 282 Porters, Servants Bayo= 178 Prisoners-Arab (used as) 45 Porters)= Total= 505
<pb facs="20170614_144218"
As the men were armed with the albini Rifle and carried 100 cartridges. Besides this ammunition 40 boxes, each containing 160 cartridges were distributed, this brought our ammunintion supply up to 34,600 cartridges.
Fifty men of at Company "B" each carried a shell or canister shot for the Cannon, and for the carriages of the piece I distrubted the Porters as follows: 12 men for cannon, weight 230 lbs in 3 details. 12 men for the carriage weight 240 lbs in 3 details. 4 men for 2 wheels, weight 50lbs each 6 men for 3 caissons, weight 40lbs. each containing 65 charges powder. The luggage consisted of 3 double Edington Tento six caup beds, 3 canteens, containing, cooking apparatus, pates, knives, forks etc. One trunk and bedding for each to buy provisions on the road, and 11 "chap boxes"
provision
<pb facs="20170614_144228"
(provisions cures) for the affairs. Each man carried his own rice cufforont for 10 days as we expected to find food for them on the road.
I would state in explanation of my having command of the cannon. The officer who had been desimated for this command was sent back to Ba- soko ill with the small fox. This made one affair short, so I tendered any ser- vices + They were accepted by the Com- mandant in the following terms;- -Translation- "Congo Free State- "The Commissary of the Arumimu- Ouelle "District on mission in the Lomemi- "Accepts the services which M. R.Dorsey "Mohew offers voluntarily, and charges "hit with the commonad of the Ar- "tillery Section of the Expedition"= Lhoms, April 19th, 1890 (2nd) L. Chaltin."- (See Appendix "A" for French Copy)-- The first days March was a
short
<pb facs="20170614_144148"
short one, as we started late. Two cases of small pox apperance that might + the men were immediately sent bacl to the Steamer, which was to stop at Bena-Kamba until written in- structions to the contray were given by Commandant Chaltin.
The next morning all were on the move at daybreak. At 11 a.m. the Vauguard were attacked by natives and in a few minutes the wholle column were engaged. Posioned arrow simply rowed and strange to say no one was struck, but one of the Corporals had a most narrow escape,-an arrow burying itself 1/2 an inch in the stock of his rifle. The grass being six or seven feet high it was impossible to locate the natives, the fighting therefore was all on their side, while we amused ourselves dodging arrows which it say the least was not a pleasant occupation. The next day crossed many large plains the soft black mud throughout their
entire
<pb facs="20170614_144157"
entire length being 1/2 foot deep ren- dered walking very different and progress slow. In one of these plains natives appeared with palm branches in their hands as a sign of peace. They had heard of an approach and asked for protection from the Arabs, who had been raiding, mur- dering and pillaging in this section for years. Two guides for Riba-Riba were given, whicch to our force, but these men, evidently thinking we were too weak to fight so many people as the Arabs had, dessented two days afterwards.
On the 24th the Welu River was reached, but the water being too high no ford was found, However all hands set to work and in two days a bridge 600 feet long + one wide was completed. On the morning of the 26th all passed over in fine order. At mid-day the village of + Kamba was reached. This is the place
where
<pb facs="20170614_144252"
where. Hodiders Expedition was massacered. Nothing was found in any way connected with this informante affair.
The Arabs had deserted I Kamba prob- ably in March. All the houses to the number of 300 were in excellent condition but all removable articles had been taken away by their owners. We lost a soldier here; he received a posioned aarow in his head, but before falling shot the native who threw the arrow. Death was almost instantaneous.
This posion is deadly in the effect and I have heard of one relatable method to counteract into effect. This made from old urine which is placed in an earthen ware pot and exposed to the rayo of the on for three days. During the time of exposure small red ants are pounded into a powder until about 3 ounces have been collected. This powder is the poured into the pot and the mess boiled for three hours, when it has attained the cnsistency of molasses it is ready for use, the amount required for three of four days is carried in a
slinsling
<pb facs="20170614_144312"
sling at the side. The arrow is dipped in and shot dripping.
That afternoon the entire town was burned and destroyed, and at 4 p.m. we left for the small village of N'bonbon +camped for the night, A cheerful sight greeted us upon entering this place; the chief of the District who has the extraordinary name of Equansalanmonated, being an ally of the Arabs, had palced directly across the road sixteen newly cut heads (of natives), probably as a warning to us what our fate would be if we proceeded farther. By directiom of the Commandant they were buried in the bush.
Small pox had now assumed serious pro- portion, some 30 cases having appeared of course it was out of the question to think of leaving these people at any pint on the road, as they would have been killed by the enemy, so we were compelled to take then with us.
March
<pb facs="20170614_144318"
March 29th progress was stopped by arriving on the edge of what ap- peared to be an immense 2 warrants. Men were sent in different directions to fuid a crossing place, Lalfan hour afterwards they returned having found a road, which led to a river which was broad and swift. and impossible to cross without a raft or boats. They were sent back to look for a better place, but soon came back reporting that a large armed force of Arabs were on the other side preparing to cross. Preparations were immediately commenced to attack. A force of men under Lt. de Bock was sent to the night; a mild force under Captain Marck to the left- Sergeants Nahan +Lamers took up the centre and the cannon was con- veyed to a point which I considered about 900 feet diagonally appoints the centre of the Arab position. All was quiet amongst our men. The enemy had not discovered our presence
and
<pb facs="20170614_144325"
and were creating the most frightful row in their camp. Horns blowing, Toms beating men yelling orders, women screeching and children crying. They had three canoes + the first load started for the other side where Captain Marek was waiting for them. Not one escaped. Of course This was the signal, and the forming because general all along our line which extended a mile along the river. Receiving orders from the Com- mandant I placed one shell in the centre of the camp. This was the only shot fired, as they shifted their pposiion + we could not transport the cannon to a favorable place. Commandant Chaltin coming up at this moment ordered me to leave the piece in charge of a sergeant + 25 soldiers, and to go with him to a place he had found directly opposite the camp. Two sol- diers were with us and we apened fire with deadly effect. When are position was discovered we received their
whole
<pb facs="20170614_144332"
whole fire. Bullets, slug, beads, and pieces of brass rads seemed to hail but no one was wounded. After three hours they withdrew and our camp was made in an open space near the river back, and in such a position it could not be attacked suddenly. The roll was called to account for dead and wounded, but we found that only one man had a slight bullet wound in his leg. Considering the heavy fire we had been exposed to it seems extraordinary that such could be the case.
Some of the men accompanied by me, swam the river, and reconnected the place, but we could not find an Arab, dead or alive. The bush was covered with blood, but all the bodies had been removed, which is a custom of these people if cir- cumstances permit.
THe next morning the construction of a raft was commenced and late
that
<pb facs="20170614_144338"
that might all being finished preparations were at once commenced to cross in the morning.
Lt. Boak all day to send over 150 men as only 5 at a time could be carried. When this member was reached it was decided to send them to Riba- Riba (3 hours distant) + to return as soon as the mission had been accom- plished. Headquarters were established on the backs of the Kassaku River.
Previous to the departure of this detachment, a couciln was "held to discuss the advisability of establish- ing a post at Riba-Riba. It was decided impracticable on account of the small pox being an epideimic (130 men having the disease). The Commandant was afraid to put so many arms + so much ammunition in the centre of the enemy's country, with the chance of all the gattidon dying of the disease, thus allowing valuable stoves to fall in the hands of the Arabs.
We were to go to Riba-Riba
do
<pb facs="20170614_144345"
do what we could and return to Kassuku, when the route for Bena- Kamba would be taken.
Riba-Riba was found to be on large town, well situated and said out. In front of chief M. Genera's house two right hands, belonging to white men were found tied to the flag staff. They probably be longed to messro. M. Chief+ Noblesse who were murdered here last year. The- place was deserted, not even a native being seen. In a short time everything was in flames, and we both up the return march to camp which was reached at 1 A.M.
May 1st all sick were sent; under a quard, back to Benas Kamba and on the 2nd the remainder of the Expedition left. We travelled 10 hours of a day reaching the Steamer May 5th at 2p.m. making the return journey in 3 days. It took us 9 days to go"
The scenes on the road going back
were
<pb facs="20170614_144354"
were awful; the dead from the sick, column buring it every mile. In many cases one would fall over a corpse, concealed by the high grass, and the stench from the dead, who had succumbed on our march to Kassaka, was overpowering.
Thirty cases appeared with us and they had to make the best- of their way back there being absoultely no method by which we could assist them.
Upon our return + the roll being called our total number was 401 persons, 104 having died in less than three weeks.
All the sick were placed in two large steel boats and sent down never under charge of a corporal + four soldiers.
Departed from Bena-Kamba May 7th and May 12th reached Isanghi at this mouth of the Lamami. This is a large Arab past and
was
